Award.AwardTitle: Congestion Options: A Market Solution to Congestion Externalities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Congestion Options, A Market Based Solution to Congestion Externalities

Terry L. Friesz and Tao Yao
Pennsylvania State University

In this project we study the idea of creating congestion rights that may be bought and sold, much as air pollution rights can now be traded. By creating a market for congestion, it is hoped that congestion can be tamed and mitigated. The main focus of our work is congestion securities, especially congestion options ? which are contracts that allow one to buy or sell the opportunity to initiate congestion-inducing movement or flow over a transport, data or voice network. Although passenger automobile traffic on metropolitan road networks is the principal focus of this research, we will also explore the impact of congestion options on urban logistics and telecommunications. Our principal tool in the study of congestion options will be computer-based models of option pricing informed by vehicular traffic and message flows in a dense urban setting, such as New York, Boston or Washington. These models will be instructed to consider circumstances like those a city dweller, commuter or tourist might experience in taking a taxi, driving to a dental appointment, sending a package or exchanging information via a PDA. In this way we will gather synthetic data describing the impacts of congestion options and markets for congestion rights. That data will be analyzed to determine the financial, economic and social implications of congestion options.

This research will provide the infrastructure engineering community with case studies, instructional aids and software useful for teaching undergraduate and graduate students how to construct and analyze markets for congestion rights. It will also provide material for informing the general public about the potential role of congestion options and congestion markets in alleviating one of the great social problems of the modern age, namely congestion. If successful, this research may establish congestion securities as a new field of specialization within financial engineering that has the potential to literally change how people commute, telecommute and employ freight services in urban environments with substantial congestion. Additionally, our research will illuminate how congestion options may be used to promote social justice for the poor when congestion pushes their jobs farther and farther from their places of residence and makes commuting by public transit prohibitively time consuming. In particular, we will show how congestion options may be written assuring payments to such groups when congestion creates an untenable commuting environment for them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to 2010 Urban Mobility Report, congestion caused extra travel of 4.8 billion hours in US in 2009. This accounts an extra 3.9 billion gallons of fuel and a $115 billion congestion cost. The rising price of fuel and the recognition of the need for a paradigm shift toward environmentally sustainable transport urge the need of a solution. Tolling, as a widely adopted scheme in traffic control and transportation infrastructure management, has been intensively investigated in academia in terms of its potential specifically to reduce congestion and actually implemented to control congestion level in some cities such as London. All these efforts actually transform the travel right to an asset which has a monetary value and ideally is tradable. Whence, not surprisingly, pricing of travel right, which is also referred to as congestion pricing in academia, has drawn lots of research efforts and attentions from industry and government in the past decades. Many studies regarding congestion pricing have revealed that like other asset pricing problem, congestion pricing suffers from nonnegligible uncertainty (i.e. inaccurate and late estimation of travel demand and travelers’ behaviors). To mitigate the negative impacts of uncertainty on congestion pricing and reduce congestion more effectively, our research project focuses on the introduction of congestion option and investigation of its potentials in improving the efficiency of congestion pricing and further the social welfare.

 

An option is a contract that permits buying or selling of an asset at or before a specified date at a specified price. It is introduced to hedge risk in asset pricing. Loosely speaking, when options involve financial assets they are called financial options; when they involve non-financial assets they are called real options. So congestion option is a specific type of real options. In this project, we have combined the classical option pricing theory and traffic modeling techniques and derived the optimal option price in terms of reducing congestion. We demonstrated by theoretical analysis and numerical experiments that due to its effectiveness, equitability and operability, congestion option is a sustainable solution to congestion mitigation. These research findings could literally change how people commute, telecommute, employ freight services in urban environments, and quantify risk in the presence of substantial congestion.

 

The project findings are widely disseminated through conference presentations and journal publications. Full lists of those outcomes can be found in the Final Report. What is more, based on recent research findings of this project, we have introduced lecture modules on congestion options for transportation and telecommunication networks into existing industrial engineering (IE) courses offered at Penn State. In these courses, interdisciplinary term projects from real applications in congestion management are assigned to offer students an opportunity to apply their knowledge and skills on real-world problems.

 

The project funding has supported/partially supported 4 graduate students including one female PhD student and one minority PhD student. During this project, the advisees (graduate students) of the PI participated through independent studies and dissertation research which enabled them to get to know how to conduct individual research as well as the required important research methodology. These students also helped disseminate the research findings by presenting their studies in various workshops, conferences and Penn State colloquiums. These experiences gained through participating in the outreach and engagement activities of this project help them develop an expertise in this area and prepare for a future academic or industrial career.
